title: Patched the ec2 driver to include instance start-stop functionality
body:
- Added ex_start_node method to the ec2 compute driver
- Added ex_stop_node method to the ec2 compute driver
- Added a new _get_state_boolean function to get the state of the node while starting or stopping

title: Set metadata - OpenStack driver
body:
From http://docs.openstack.org/cactus/openstack-compute/developer/openstack-compute-api-1.1/content/ServerUpdate.html:

This operation updates the editable attributes of a server: the name of the server, the server metadata, and the IPv4 and IPv6 access address. Note that while the server name is editable, the operation does not change the server host name. Note also that server names are not guaranteed to be unique.

title: Nova client with novaclient - Proof of Concept
body:
This pull request represents a new OpenStack driver based on python-novaclient. There are no tests at this time, so it's not ready to merge. I wanted to spark some discussion on this possibility, which I am very much for. python-novaclient is actually used internally by Rackspace and other OpenStack providers, so this is likely to be extremely well-maintained, plus novaclient already covers a lot of corner cases. To do it from scratch in libcloud results in a great deal of duplication of work and code, and would probably still lag on robustness unless we were to actually tediously crib nearly all of the novaclient logic.

BTW, the first commit collapses the OpenStack 1.0 driver into the Rackspace driver (the only public implementation of OpenStack 1.0), as has been discussed recently on the mailing list and in IRC, resulting in a general consensus that this is a good thing to do. Aside from that, the bit you really want to look at for the novaclient-based driver is _all_ in [libcloud/compute/drivers/openstack.py](https://github.com/racker/libcloud/blob/nova-client-with-novaclient/libcloud/compute/drivers/openstack.py). Seriously, the diff is useless for that file.

This is a proposed solution for https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-83

title: Fix inheritance inversion
body:
In the current state of the computer drivers, the exists an inverted inheritance in that OpenStack inherits from Rackspace, where Rackspace (and potentially other specific OpenStack providers) should rather inherit from OpenStack. This inversion complicated several things: 
- Support for multiple OpenStack providers. 
- Support for multiiple OpenStack API versions in general. 
- Separately, future migration of the Rackspace driver to a new OpenStack version (e.g. migrating Rackspace to OpenStack 1.1 would migrate all OpenStack subclasses to 1.1).

Upstream issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-110

title: OpenStack driver fixes
body:
I have faced with 2 issues in the OpenStack driver:
1. the driver uses Rackspace pricing - it looks weird and causes error if OpenStack cloud contains 8+ flavors. From my point of view it's better to set the price 0.0 for all flavors by default (user is allowed to provide custom pricing).
2. Sometimes response doesn't contain valid XML - it contains plaint text like 'Request accepted'. It causes MalformedResponseError. So I added content-type header examination.

repo.description: Apache Libcloud is a Python library which hides differences between different cloud provider APIs and allows you to manage different cloud resources through a unified and easy to use API.

title: Rackspace enhancements
body:
For the Rackspace driver, create_node() and deploy_node() return different node references unnecessarily.  The create_node() method returns a node instance with password populated in extra, while deploy_node() returns a node from list_nodes(), which does not include passwords.  I've modified base.NodeDriver.deploy_node() to return the node instance it gets from calling create_node(), thus including the password.

I've also modified drivers.rackspace.RackspaceNodeDriver and added set_password() and set_server_name() methods, along with a private implementation method and modifying request() to make PUT use xml.  These changes expand the API to make available the Rackspace API methods for changing the password and server name.
